snippet: Stockton has gone through what Detroit faces and hopes to emerge from bankruptcy protection in the spring. But its biggest problem, pension payments, still looms.
abstract: Stockton, Calif, is nearly ready to leave court protection after laboring for months to find its way out of Chapter 9 bankruptcy; unlike Detroit, however, which was allowed to reduce its public pensions to help shed debt, Stockton has become an experiment of whether a municipality can successfully come out of bankruptcy and stabilize its finances without touching pensions; effort has come at great cost to city services and is one that some critics say will simply not work.

byline.original: By RICK LYMAN and MARY WILLIAMS WALSH

lead_paragraph: Stockton has gone through what Detroit faces and hopes to emerge from bankruptcy protection in the spring. But its biggest problem, pension payments, still looms.

headline.main: California City’s Return to Solvency, With Pension Problem Unsolved
headline.print_headline: One City’s Return to Solvency Leaves Big Problem Unsolved
